flashcards.english: Gũcũnga (to doze), Gũkoma (to sleep), Gũkoma na nda (sleep on stomach/face down), Gũkoma na ngara/mũgongo (sleep on back), Gũkoma na mwena (sleep on one side), Kũrara (to spend the night), Hinga maitho ũkome (shut your eyes and sleep), Rara nĩ gwatuka (sleep-over, darkness has fallen), Koma ũkĩre (sleep and wake up), Koma na wega/thayũ (sleep well), Gĩa/Korwo na ũtuko mwega (have a good night)
flashcards.notes: Comprehensive sleep vocabulary. Note: Kũrara means to spend the night (not just to sleep). Examples: Rara ũgathie rĩciũ (sleep over and go tomorrow), Kaĩ ũkomaga ũhingũrĩte maitho? (do you sleep with eyes open?)
Common domestic and pest animals vocabulary

flashcards.kikuyu: Simple Vocabulary with Consonants G, H, K
flashcards.notes: Basic vocabulary demonstrating consonant sounds g, h, k. Example sentences: Gĩra gĩkombe gĩkĩ (come for this cup), Kaĩrĩtu kena karamu (the girl has a pen), Kana kona kora (the child saw a frog)

flashcards.english: Mwaburi/Mĩaburi (umbrella sing/plur), Mũbĩra/Mĩbĩra (ball sing/plur), Kĩratũ/Iratũ (shoe sing/plur), Ngaari (car)
flashcards.notes: Common objects showing singular/plural patterns. Class patterns: Mũ-/Mĩ- for umbrella and ball, Kĩ-/I- for shoe

flashcards.english: Ĩta (call), Aria (speak), Eterera (wait), Ceera (visit), Uga (say), Andĩka (write), Ona (see), Enja (shave/dig a hole), Nyua (drink), Uma (get out), Kena (be happy), Kora (find), Koma (sleep), Batara (need), Rĩma (dig in a farm), Rota (dream), Ruga (cook)
flashcards.notes: 17 essential verbs in infinitive form (without Kũ-/Gũ- prefix). Note polysemy: Enja can mean shave OR dig a hole (context-dependent)
